summary: This document is a series of forwarded emails from Christopher J. Dilorio, a self-proclaimed whistleblower, to various recipients including SEC officials, FBI agents, and SDNY judges. It contains allegations of widespread corruption, obstruction, and criminal facilitation by the SEC and other agencies, specifically related to market manipulation, money laundering through OTC markets, and the protection of entities like Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial. Dilorio references his own TCRs (Tip, Complaint, or Referral) and claims the SEC is actively using his information while denying him whistleblower awards and covering up frauds.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of SEC, DOJ, and FBI corruption, market manipulation, and money laundering. He claims to be a whistleblower whose information has been ignored or misused.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.role: SEC Official (likely Office of the Whistleblower)
persons.context: Referred to as 'Janey', she is the recipient of many emails and is accused of lying and obstructing the investigation into Dilorio's claims. She issued a preliminary denial of his whistleblower award.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: Described as a prolific 'bag man' involved with money laundering shells like Balance Labs, Incubator, and Skyway. Allegedly on an SEC 'Do not investigate list' and connected to Stephen Adams.

persons.name: Richard Handler
persons.context: Accused of having a corrupt, criminal relationship with the SEC. Implicated in the Knight Capital/Virtu Financial merger and the alleged setup of Dan Kamensky.

persons.name: Douglas Cifu
persons.context: CEO of Virtu Financial (NITE). Accused of hiding OTCM trading volumes that drive revenue, engaging in accounting fraud, and being part of a corrupt relationship with the SEC and Handler.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Subject of an SDNY criminal case brought by prosecutors Strauss and Cooper. Dilorio claims the case is a fraud and a setup orchestrated by Handler/Jefferies and the SEC, and that Kamensky is innocent.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: SEC Chairman accused of corruption, conflicts of interest due to his Sullivan & Cromwell background, and facilitating frauds. Allegedly did not recuse himself from relevant matters.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Named as a 'bag man' involved in fraudulent convertible note assignments and money laundering shells like CGFIA, IMDS, NewLead. Subject of an SEC complaint that Dilorio claims is based on his information.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Another alleged 'bag man' detailed in Dilorio's 2013 TCR. Involved with World Trade Financial and later with Blink Charging (New Image Concepts). Barred by FINRA as a 'Bad Actor'.

persons.name: Robert Sollazzo
persons.role: Former SEC NY Broker-Dealer Exam Leader
persons.context: Retired SEC official accused of obstructing investigations into criminal broker-dealers like Knight Capital (NITE) during his 38-year career.

persons.name: Richard Best
persons.context: Named Director of SEC NY. Previously at FINRA where he brought a BBH AML complaint that Dilorio claims omitted key entities from his TCR. Accused of covering up.

persons.name: Michael Rufino
persons.context: Former FINRA executive who joined the SEC NY office. Accused, like Sollazzo and Best, of doing nothing to stop frauds like NITE during his long tenure at FINRA.

persons.name: Sigal Mandelker
persons.context: Former Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence at Treasury. Noted that her critical audit report on Russian money laundering was followed by her not being replaced, which Dilorio implies was intentional.

persons.name: Stephen Adams
persons.context: Billboard magnate and businessman linked to Michael Farkas. Noted as a Bush fundraiser and pro-Trump campaign donor.

persons.name: Glenn Hutchins
persons.role: Co-founder of Silver Lake, North Island
persons.context: Co-founder of Silver Lake, former Blackstone executive. Bought SunGard with Robert Greifeld and formed North Island, a top shareholder in Virtu Financial (NITE). Implicated in money laundering connections.

persons.name: Robert Greifeld
persons.context: Former NASDAQ CEO, co-founded North Island with Glenn Hutchins. Previously at SunGard. Implicated in facilitating real-time ruble-to-dollar conversion and connections to Russian entity Otkritie.

persons.name: Adena Friedman
persons.context: CEO of NASDAQ who signed off on the acquisition of Verafin. Implicated in the NASDAQ's role with AQR blank check shells and SunGard/Brut transactions.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Sullivan & Cromwell colleague of Jay Clayton. Accused of playing a key role in keeping Knight/Virtu Financial operational and involved in the VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: SDNY Attorney prosecuting Dan Kamensky. Accused by Dilorio of being part of a fraudulent case and withholding exculpatory evidence.

persons.name: Marc Berger
persons.context: SEC official to whom Dilorio submitted his initial TCR in March 2013. Later moved to Enforcement.

persons.name: David Blostein
persons.context: Goldman Sachs analyst covering Virtu Financial. Accused by Dilorio of knowing about and failing to model the crucial OTCM share volumes that drive NITE's revenue.

persons.name: Ebrahim Daoud Nonoo
persons.context: Bahraini businessman linked to AppTech's deal with NEC Payments (Bahrain), cited as an example of international money laundering connections.

connections.description: Dilorio is a whistleblower whose award claims were preliminarily denied by Norberg's office at the SEC OWB. He accuses her of lying, obstruction, and being part of a criminal cover-up.
Handler (Jefferies) and Cifu (Virtu) are accused of orchestrating the VIRT/KCG merger with SEC facilitation, using fraudulent balance sheet valuations, and having a corrupt relationship with the SEC.

Dilorio alleges a deep, corrupt relationship where the SEC actively facilitates and covers up NITE's core business of abusive naked shorting and money laundering via OTC shells, protecting it from investigation.
Linked through business ventures like Skyway and Incubator. Both are portrayed as 'bag men' involved in money laundering shells and political fundraising.
Both are described as 'bag men' who acquire and assign fraudulent convertible notes to create worthless securities for money laundering, as detailed in Dilorio's TCRs.
Colleagues from Sullivan & Cromwell. Dilorio alleges Clayton's conflicts of interest due to this relationship, and that Fishman helped keep NITE operational.
Co-founded North Island private equity firm after Hutchins bought and sold SunGard. North Island is a top shareholder in Virtu Financial (NITE).
Former colleagues at FINRA who both moved to senior positions in the SEC's New York office. Accused of continuing a pattern of not investigating entities like NITE.
Dilorio claims Kamensky's criminal case is a fraud and a setup orchestrated by Handler and Jefferies, with whom Kamensky was in a bankruptcy dispute.
Strauss worked under former SDNY Attorney Preet Bharara. Dilorio claims both have been in possession of his whistleblower information for some time.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: A trading glitch at Knight Capital Group caused a $440 million loss, nearly bankrupting the firm. Dilorio claims this proved Knight was insolvent due to its core business of abusive naked shorting and was covered up with a bailout.

events.title: Dilorio's Initial TCR Submission
events.description: Christopher Dilorio submitted his first Tip, Complaint, or Referral (TCR) to SEC official Marc Berger, detailing allegations against Knight Capital (NITE), money laundering shells, and various 'bag men'.

events.title: Virtu Financial Acquisition of KCG Holdings
events.description: Virtu Financial acquired KCG Holdings in a $1.4 billion all-cash merger. Dilorio alleges the deal was fraudulent, that KCG was insolvent, and that the SEC, Handler, and Cifu wrote down $4+ billion in fraudulent 'assets' to inflate the price.

events.title: SDNY Case Against Dan Kamensky
events.description: The SDNY, led by Audrey Strauss, brought criminal charges against Dan Kamensky related to the Neiman Marcus bankruptcy. Dilorio claims this case is a fraudulent setup orchestrated by Richard Handler/Jefferies and facilitated by a corrupt SEC/SDNY relationship.

events.title: Dilorio's Email Blast Alleging Ongoing Fraud
events.description: Christopher Dilorio sends a massive email chain to SEC officials, FBI agents, and SDNY judges, reiterating allegations of ongoing SEC-facilitated frauds involving Blink Charging, Net Element, and others, and demanding immediate investigations and actions.

events.title: NASDAQ Acquires Verafin
events.description: NASDAQ announced a $2.8 billion acquisition of Verafin, a financial crimes detection firm. Dilorio cites this as evidence that NASDAQ has a massive money laundering problem it is trying to address, related to AQR shells and other issues he reported.

locations: Miami Beach, FL 33139 (1111 Lincoln Road, 4th Floor - referenced as address for registrant)
Newport Beach, California (Anton & Chia, LLP headquarters)
New York, NY (SDNY, SEC NY Office, financial hub)
Russia (Frequently referenced in context of money laundering, Otkritie, Net Element servers)
Bahrain (NEC Payments location linked to AppTech)
keyFacts: Christopher Dilorio claims to be a whistleblower whose detailed TCRs and hundreds of emails since 2013 have been ignored or misused by the SEC, which he alleges is a 'grossly corrupt criminal organization' actively facilitating fraud.

A core allegation is that Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial's (NITE) primary business is abusive naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering, and that the SEC has protected this activity for years.

Dilorio asserts a corrupt relationship exists between the SEC, SDNY, and Richard Handler/Jefferies, which he claims is central to the fraudulent VIRT/KCG merger and the setup of Dan Kamensky in the SDNY case.

He provides specific examples of alleged SEC obstruction, including the preliminary denial of his whistleblower award based on the claim 'SEC investigators never saw my information,' which he calls a blatant lie.

The emails reference numerous specific companies and individuals allegedly involved in money laundering ecosystems, including Blink Charging, Net Element, AppTech, Balance Labs, and 'bag men' like Michael Farkas, Joshua Sason, and Justin Keener.
